title.narrative: PREVENTING VIOLENCE IN SCHOOLS

description.narrative: By 2016, duty bearers in the education sector and rights-holders have knowledge and skills to prevent violence against children in school-based settings., which contributes to Cross-Sectoral Communication For Development, Equitable Access To Quality Education, Evaluation And Research. UNICEF aims to achieve this through Evaluations, Research And Data, Systems Strengthening And Institution Building. This contributes to the following Country Programme result: By 2016 all boys and girls from the poorest communities are accessing pre-school and early stimulation opportunities, are benefiting from positive child-centered approaches at school and are benefitting from law and polices that protect them from neglect, violence, exploitation and discrimination.

condition.narrative: Should contribute directly to results for children as outlined in the UNDAF, national results and/or UNICEF Strategic Plan and within the scope defined in the CPD, CPAP, OMP or other agreed upon programme documents

title.narrative: By 2016, duty bearers in the education sector and rights-holders have knowledge and skills to prevent violence against children inschool-based settings.

description.narrative: Violence in schools in the form of bullying and the administration of corporal punishment remains an issue to be addressed; however some strides have been made in addressing the issue as a result of key partnership, advocacy and commitment by MoE to implement PBM strategies | Status:On-track | As-of Date:06/01/2017

title.narrative: % of newly sensitized civil society groups and persons interacting with school-aged children (Scouts, Brownies, coaches, religious leaders, parents etc.). in 8 countries, who have increased knowledge and skills on alternatives to corporal punishment

actual.value: 2015:An additional 965 non-educators (parents, coaches, security guards, crossing guards, and religious lay workers media) were sensitized in Grenada, Barbados, Tobago and Dominica on PBM. Barbados completed its handbooks for parents (pre- secondary) on PBM. While Dominica and Montserrat continued to

title.narrative: % of children in 8 countries, ages 8 12 years in CFS schools who know what to do and who know who to turn to in case of bullying

baseline.value: 80% of girls and boys in Grenada , 80% SKN, 80% Tobago, 86% St. Vincent & the Grenadines, 67% Barbados, Anguilla 80 (2014), Antigua 97 (2014), Dominica 98 (2014), St. Lucia 96 (2014)

actual.value: 2015:Only 2 countries (Anguilla and Trinidad) engaged in interventions to address bullying. In Anguilla 75 per cent of the primary school students were reached through anti bullying song and dance. Anguilla also held a multi-stakeholder meeting to devise a comprehensive strategy to address bullying. In

title.narrative: % of trained educators (pre-secondary) in 8 countries who have increased knowledge and skills on alternatives to corporal punishment

baseline.value: Barbados 94%, 88% Antigua, 92% St. Lucia, 100% SVG, 92% Dominica

actual.value: 2016:an additional 666 educators across 8 countries have enhanced skills and knowledge to implement PBM
